moe_section_title: HTA / Certifying Staff Authorisation, Training and Personnel Records
summary: Describes requirements for HTA (certifying staff) experience and licence, one‑time and limited HTA authorisations (including for pilots/commanders), training system (induction, refresher, recurrent, training planning and delivery), type training practical internship per Part‑66, personnel records, and quality assessors/inspectors.

findings.requirement_excerpt: Holding a Part-66 licence with the relevant type/group rating ... does not mean by itself that the holder is qualified to be authorised as certifying staff and/or support staff. The organisation is responsible for assessing the competency of the holder ... The organisation should specifically ensure that the individual competencies have been established with regard to: relevant knowledge, skills and experience ... and knowledge of the associated organisation and operator procedures.
findings.reasoning: The MOE requires HTA personnel to have at least 5 years’ maintenance experience and a valid ICAO maintenance licence with type rating, and it states that the organisation obtains and maintains evidence of experience and licence. It also describes induction, refresher and recurrent training (including Part‑145/MOE procedures, human factors, technical data, etc.) and that training achievements are recorded. However, it does not clearly describe a structured competency assessment process (initial and recurrent) to verify that licence holders are competent for the specific scope of authorisation, nor does it explicitly address assessment of differences between generic type training and the specific aircraft configuration.

findings.requirement_id: 145.A.30(h) & AMC1 145.A.30(h) – identical qualification requirements for certifying and support staff
findings.requirement_excerpt: the qualification requirements (basic licence, aircraft ratings, recent experience and recurrent training) are identical for certifying staff and for support staff.
findings.reasoning: The MOE describes HTA (certifying staff) qualifications and mentions that HTAs may act as support persons for category C staff, but it does not explicitly state that support staff must meet the same basic licence, type rating, recent experience and recurrent training requirements as certifying staff. The linkage between support staff roles and their qualification requirements is not clearly defined.
findings.recommended_fix:
Insert explicit text such as:

"Support staff used in base maintenance shall meet the same qualification requirements as certifying staff for the relevant aircraft and tasks (basic Part‑66 licence, appropriate aircraft ratings, recent experience and recurrent training), in accordance with 145.A.30(h) and AMC1 145.A.30(h). Where a person already holds line maintenance certification privileges, these may be used when acting as support staff, but the person’s qualifications and recent experience shall be verified and recorded before assigning support staff duties."

findings.requirement_id: 145.A.30(j)(4) & AMC1 145.A.30(j)(4) – limited certification authorisation for pilots
findings.requirement_excerpt: For the issue of a limited certification authorisation, the pilot should hold either an ATPL or a CPL ... In addition, the limited certification authorisation is subject to the MOE containing procedures to address the personnel requirements of point 145.A.30(e). The procedures should include as a minimum: (a) completion of adequate continuing airworthiness regulation training as related to maintenance; (b) completion of adequate task training for the specific task(s) on the aircraft ...; (c) completion of the procedural training as specified in Part-145. Typical tasks that may be certified ... are the minor maintenance or simple checks included in the following list...
findings.reasoning: The MOE allows limited HTA authorisation to be granted to a commander or flight engineer based on specific training and a performance test, with a maximum validity of one year. However, it does not explicitly require the pilot to hold an ATPL or CPL, does not clearly define the required continuing airworthiness regulation training and procedural training, and does not limit the scope of tasks to a defined list of minor/simple tasks consistent with the AMC. The reference to tasks is generic (e.g. airworthiness directive performance) and could exceed the intended scope for pilot authorisations.

findings.requirement_excerpt: Issuing a one-off authorisation should only be considered under the responsibility of the compliance monitoring manager ... after a reasoned judgement ... A one-off authorisation should not be issued if the level of certification required could exceed the knowledge and experience level of the person ... The organisation has an approved procedure in place for coordinating and controlling the total maintenance activity ... full technical details ... step-by-step worksheet ... person holds authorisations of equivalent levels and scopes on other aircraft types that have similar technology...
findings.reasoning: The MOE mentions that a one‑time HTA authorisation will be announced to the NAA within 7 days, but it does not define any of the required controls: no role of the compliance monitoring manager, no requirement for individual assessment of each situation, no verification of equivalent authorisations on similar aircraft, no requirement for full technical details and step‑by‑step worksheets, and no procedure for coordinating and controlling maintenance at the location. The process is therefore incomplete and not aligned with the AMC.

findings.requirement_excerpt: The holder of a category B2 aircraft maintenance licence may only exercise the certification privileges described in point 66.A.20(a)(3)(ii) ... following the satisfactory completion of: (i) the relevant category A aircraft task training; and (ii) 6 months of documented practical experience covering the scope of the authorisation ... Task training and examination/assessment shall be carried out by the maintenance organisation issuing the certifying staff authorisation. The practical experience shall be also obtained within such maintenance organisation.
findings.reasoning: The MOE section describes general HTA qualification and training, but it does not address the specific case of B2 licence holders being granted A‑type line maintenance privileges, nor does it define the required category A task training, 6 months of documented practical experience, and in‑house assessment as required by 145.A.35(n) and AMC1 145.A.35(n).
findings.recommended_fix:
Add a subsection such as:

"B2 certifying staff exercising A‑type privileges

Where a B2 licence holder is to be granted certification privileges in accordance with 66.A.20(a)(3)(ii) (minor scheduled line maintenance and simple defect rectification), the following conditions shall be met before issuing the authorisation:
  - completion of relevant category A aircraft task training (theoretical and practical hands‑on) for the tasks to be authorised, delivered by this organisation;
  - successful completion of an examination or workplace assessment for the authorised tasks, carried out by this organisation;
  - at least 6 months of documented practical experience within this organisation, covering the scope of the intended authorisation.

The training, assessments and experience shall be recorded in the person’s training and authorisation file. The authorisation scope shall clearly list the tasks covered by the A‑type privileges."

findings.requirement_id: 145.A.30(d) & AMC1 145.A.30(d) – sufficient number of personnel / man‑hour planning
findings.requirement_excerpt: Has sufficient staff means that the organisation employs or contracts competent staff, as detailed in the man-hour plan ... The maintenance man-hour plan should take into account all maintenance activities ... should be reviewed at least every 3 months and updated when necessary ... Significant deviation from the maintenance man-hour plan should be reported ...
findings.reasoning: This MOE section focuses on individual qualifications, training and personnel records. It does not describe any man‑hour planning, review of staffing levels, or procedures to address deviations from the plan as required by AMC1 145.A.30(d). If this topic is covered elsewhere in the MOE, it is not evident in this section; within this section the requirement is not addressed.
findings.recommended_fix:
If not already covered in another MOE chapter, add a cross‑reference or a brief statement here, for example:

"The organisation ensures a sufficient number of competent personnel through a documented maintenance man‑hour planning process, including quarterly review and deviation management, as described in MOE section [x.x.x] in accordance with 145.A.30(d) and AMC1 145.A.30(d)."

findings.requirement_excerpt: In order to be approved to carry out airworthiness reviews and to issue the corresponding airworthiness review certificates (ARC) ... the organisation shall have airworthiness review staff that comply with ... experience in continuing airworthiness ... certifying staff authorisation ... knowledge of Part-M/Part-ML Subpart C and of the procedures of the maintenance organisation relevant to the airworthiness review...
findings.reasoning: The MOE section does not mention airworthiness review staff or ARCs. It is not clear whether the organisation intends to perform airworthiness reviews under 145.A.37. If it does, the necessary requirements for airworthiness review staff are not described here; if it does not, this may be outside the scope of this section.
findings.recommended_fix:
Clarify the scope in this section, for example:

"This organisation [does/does not] perform airworthiness reviews and issue ARCs under 145.A.37. If applicable, the qualification and authorisation of airworthiness review staff are described in MOE section [y.y.y]."

findings.requirement_id: Personnel records – implied by 145.A.30 & 145.A.35 (no explicit excerpt)
findings.requirement_excerpt: The organisation shall ensure that certifying staff and support staff have an adequate understanding ... training shall be demonstrated by an examination or by workplace assessment ... The organisation is responsible for assessing the competency of the holder ...
findings.reasoning: The MOE describes a comprehensive personnel register including name, DOB, job description, work experience, basic and vocational training, type and special training, recurrent training, authorisations and qualifications, and licence copies. It defines access rights, storage, document verification by the quality manager, and retention for three years after leaving. This supports traceability of qualifications, training and authorisations in line with Part‑145 expectations.

findings.requirement_id: Training and recurrent training – linked to 145.A.35 & AMC 145.A.35(a)
findings.requirement_excerpt: The organisation shall ensure that certifying staff and support staff have an adequate understanding ... training shall be demonstrated by an examination or by workplace assessment carried out by the organisation.
findings.reasoning: The MOE defines induction, refresher and recurrent training, including technical data, Part‑145/MOE procedures, and safety/human factors, with minimum durations (e.g. at least 8 hours every two years or 4 hours annually). It states that training achievements are recorded and that training may include exams with recorded results. However, it does not clearly state that satisfactory completion of training for certifying/support staff is always demonstrated by examination or workplace assessment, nor does it explicitly link recurrent training completion to renewal of authorisations.
findings.recommended_fix:
Clarify that for certifying and support staff, completion of required training is always verified by exam or workplace assessment, and link this to authorisation validity, e.g.:

"For certifying staff and support staff, satisfactory completion of initial, refresher and recurrent training relevant to their authorisation shall be demonstrated by written examination and/or workplace assessment conducted by the organisation. The results are recorded in the training records. Renewal or extension of HTA authorisations is conditional on completion of the required recurrent training and satisfactory assessment results."

findings.requirement_id: Type training practical internship – Part‑66 Appendix III (referenced in excerpt 3)
findings.requirement_excerpt: Practical exercises ... organised in accordance with Part-66 Appendix III, section 3.2 ... at least 50 % ... tasks shall provide a comprehensive cross-section of maintenance tasks essential to the type ... Assessments will be organised in accordance with Part-66 Appendix III, Section 4.2 ... recorded in a logbook ...
findings.reasoning: The MOE describes that the organisation may arrange practical training for type training within its scope of work, in a manner approved by the NAA, referencing Part‑66.A.45, Appendix III sections 3.2 and 4.2, and AMC‑66 Appendix III. It states that exercises cover at least 50% of the task list, include essential and demanding tasks, that assessments are performed by named evaluators who are certifying staff for the type and familiar with Part‑66 requirements, and that all exercises and assessments are recorded in a logbook template based on Appendix III. This aligns well with the referenced requirements.
